response.answer_text: Now that Quora has merged the troll’s question with some people who asked more seriously, my answer needs revision. But I’ll leave my ‘troll-response’ below!  My dad was quite intelligent, but in a small town sort of way. Many years ago, as my education was in process, it was inevitable that we had a variety of heated discussions. These became progressively more frustrating to me. He was fairly proud of his debating ability (he’d won some state-wide contest when he was in high school) and of his mastery of ‘Robert’s Rules’ (which came into play in an avocational area of his life). As a young person, I naively thought these things meant he’d act and argue rationally. So I was frustrated and confused by what I actually encountered, and it took me years to find a way to describe it. Daddy could be quite logical and rational, but wasn’t most of the time. For him, logic and reason were tools in his toolbox, to be taken out and used in discussions where other methods weren’t working. But rational, reasoned, logical thought was NOT his natural mode of mental process. Now, nobody is rational all the time . . . because we don’t have time for it. Daniel Kahneman’s book, Thinking Fast and Slow, covers this extensively and persuasively. But that’s not what I mean. My maternal grandfather was not as bright, in a school-ish sense, as my father but was the only man (or woman) I’ve ever known who ALWAYS attempted to act in accord with reasoned thought. Most people are like Daddy was: if they lose a reasoned argument (and I mean, lose so that even THEY know they lost), they do NOT change their mind or behavior. Instead, they just go look for new arguments. But when Granddaddy lost an argument (and he lost a few to me), he check around to verify that I was right . . . and if I was, he’d attempt to change both his thinking and his behavior. As far as I myself know, he’s the only reasonable person that ever lived. I try, but I don’t live like he did. Of course, my knowledge doesn’t extend beyond a few thousand people. So there may well be others who are like he was. But I’ve never met them. Right now, the only candidate I’ve seen is Jordan Peterson . . . who SEEMS like he cares enough about truth to change his mind when he’s shown to be wrong. But I’ve been reading (or listening to) his material for less than a year, and I’ve never met the man. So we’ll see. But are people generally reasonable, like my Grandfather? Nope. Many people aren’t even capable of reasoned thought. But even for those who are, “reason” and “logic” and “rationality” are usually just tools they use against others, and not the preferred mode of their own INTERNAL thought.  Original Troll Response (prior to Quora question-merging) follows: With respect to your question, “Are humans reasonable?” here’s a relevant Q & A from Quora:  Q: “How does [ name of person who asked this question removed to avoid BNBR violation ] come up with such interesting questions?” A: [ name of person who asked this question removed to avoid BNBR violation ] , Just an ordinary person with no extensive knowledge on anything. Answered Oct 21, 2016 “I have no boundaries when it comes to questions, I ask anything that randomly occurs to me throughout the day, no matter how stupid, absurd or controversial it may be, and I do my best to ask questions that haven’t been asked yet.”  So . . . it would appear that at least some humans are not reasonable, but instead prefer cranial flatulence to reasonable thought. Perhaps they hope that like Zeus, they will have something wonderful spring fully formed from their minds, if only they allow whatever is there to dribble out. Unfortunately, what often seems to result brings to mind the old person’s maxim, “Never trust a fart!”. I’m afraid these random mind dribbles usually bear more resemblance to wet farts, than to a goddess of wisdom like Athena - Wiki.

Most people probably believe we are. The ancient philosophers believed that we have a rational sense and Christianity extended on this when it created the Christian theology, in which rationality is given to us by God. Most religions seem to contain a belief that humans are capable of reaching perfect understanding. However, the belief in rationality has many challenges. One of them has always been: what about the stupid people. What about those who are mentally challenged, what about children, or what about those who seem very irrational. I don’t know if it was David Hume who first started questioned the belief in pure reason: Hume strove to create a total naturalistic science of man that examined the psychological basis of human nature. Against philosophical rationalists, Hume held that passion rather than reason governs human behaviour. Hume argued against the existence of innate ideas, positing that all human knowledge is founded solely in experience. David Hume - Wikipedia The debate was not settled with Hume though. One might say that libertarianism and other ideas from economists at the Chicago school might be the strongest current force in the belief that humans are rational. The basis of libertarianism is that humans act rationally in their own self-interest. If this assumption is wrong, libertarianism will fail. That happens if a human has one choice that is good for him and one choice that is bad, and still chooses the bad one. But here we also see the challenge in the rational mind: what does it mean to be “good” and “bad” for a person? Sometimes a person might make a choice that seems like a bad choice, such as start selling drugs, but it might give him money and status he might not otherwise have. Using drugs might also seem like a bad idea, but for a person without any hopes of a future, it might be their only source of joy — and it might even activate them and give them a reason to live, rather than them become passive, depressed and develop mental problems. Most intelligent people probably believe in the rational mind, since rationality is a common way to debate: we present arguments from different sides and chose the best one. But in real life, it doesn’t always work like that, because we can’t always compare the choices. I learned this while I looked into Scientology for a few months. I believed that through rationality and intelligence, it would be possible to realize the errors of Scientology and not get caught, but what I discovered is that humans are easy to make to believe things. The way to make people believe something is not to tell them what to believe, but in asking them the right questions, or giving them suggestions with a desired outcome. After leaving Scientology, I discovered that our whole society operates on the same principles, and indeed that religions do it very strongly. Many people chose to stay in a religion simply because they are terrified of hell. From a rational perspective, their choice actually makes sense: The religion tells me that if I become a heretic (or dissident, etc), I will go to hellThe religion tells me that any attempts to make me question my faith comes from evil forces (“Satan”, etc) that makes me want to go to hell.From this perspective, it makes perfectly sense for a believer to distance themselves aggressively from any criticism against their religion. It isn’t that hard to make the next step in the thought process, and say What if I showed you a way of thinking that will remove all your negative/hateful feelings and make you a good person? -Okay that seems like it has no downsides. Then suppose we could help other people accomplish the same, and together we could eradicate evil from this world? -Wow, that sounds amazing. If I said this was Scientology, the person who believes himself to be rational would say that this way of thinking is nonsense. But suppose I said it is leftist thinking. Then many people believe it is the way to go. One can quickly draw a parallel to socialism. Based on this line of thinking, socialism is perfectly rational, but so is Scientology and any other religion. It is worth pointing out that the liberal tradition (which is the foundation of libertarianism) is based on the assumption that the individual should be free to make the decisions he wants in his life. In real life, the traditional liberal ideas never pan out. In Sweden, the liberal party (called Folkpartiet at the time), split in the 1923 over whether alcohol should be made illegal or not. Should people be free to ruin their own lives and the lives or others close to them? Liberalism, free-to-chose and individual freedom always sound good, but politicians mainly use the phrases to win votes. (imagine a politician running on saying he wants less freedom) I think rationality makes sense if we understand human nature though. For one thing, we want to belong to a group. Unlike what the media and movies tell us, we aren’t “created” to tell the truth, but we want to say things in a way that wins approval. There isn’t necessarily anything wrong with that. Just imagine a society where everyone is perfectly honest all the time, and I don’t think that would be a functioning society. It is worth pointing out that humans are unable to hide most emotions, such as anger, disgust or sadness, but are excellent at lying. Xenophobia, and maybe even racism, is also rational from a human perspective. Leftists tell us that xenophobia is irrational, but experience from around the world show that we quickly divide people into different groups and treat them stereotypical based on our experiences. That’s how our minds work. We create hierarchies where we want to see ourselves striving to be in the top, unlike others who we consider not being up to standard. This necessitates us to look for a boogeyman, as thus, as the sociologist Durkheim noted, crime is a necessary element in any society.[1] Footnotes[1] Durkheim: Crime Will Always Be In Existence

I will answer from the philosophy of GWF Hegel (ca. 1820). People are PARTLY rational and PARTLY irrational. We are a complex combination of the two, opposite features. That is, if Rationality is the thesis, then Irrationality is the antithesis, and then Humanity is the synthesis. The same applies in the realm of Ethics, morality and religion. Hegel says that human beings are basically EQUAL parts of Good and Evil. We have the potential for enormous Good. We also have the potential for enormous Evil. Hegel did not live to see the 20th century, which proved his theory in flying colors. Look at all the scientific and technological advances of the 20th century — we are clearly a rational species. Now look at all the war and genocide in the 20th century — we are clearly an irrational species. We are BOTH, said Hegel, BOTH in ONE. That is what makes Humanity so unique in the Cosmos — so complex — so interesting. This is precisely who we are. We are a part of all this. When we look inside ourselves, we can find our genuine love for the Good and for the Righteous — and we can also find the Underground Man in the byways of our minds. Nor was Hegel the first to say this. Socrates, Plato and Aristotle had already said this 2,300 years ago. The human soul, they agreed, is comprised of three basic parts — Reason, Passions and Appetites — i.e. the rational and the irrational. The well-ordered soul would organize the mind (like a city-state) so that Reason was in charge of the other forces. Yet Socrates, Plato and Aristotle were under no illusions that most people would be able to control their Passions and Appetites. Only those few who attained Excellence in Reason would be fit to govern the Republic, they declared.

Are humans fundamentally rational? Why or why not? Of course not, at least if I read your question right — most humans, most of the time, ie “fundamentally” (as the foundation for most of their choices), aren rational. I don’t see how anyone could suppose the contrary. A small number of human beings, in very special circumstances, can certainly be “fundamentally rational” — the CPA who does my taxes (I hope), the engineers designing avionics for a new passenger jet (I really hope), a scientist pursuing some avenue of research (but maybe not when trying to get funding for it or angling for a Nobel). People are animals, motivated by the usual hormones and reflexes and survival instincts — love, hate, fear, lust, mistrust, caution, jealousy, resentment, social dominance or abasement, the tendency to follow the herd, knuckle under, fight or flee, please others, tease others, pursue what tastes or feels or sounds or smells good, avoid what doesn’t, hoard stuff, poke around out of curiosity, behave differently toward family, friends, strangers, enemies, offspring, infants, the opposite sex, the same sex, other animals. Being smart animals, we dress up those things in all sorts of ways, often using our rational faculties. And as I said, a few of us are really weird and get obsessed with some pursuit where we deploy reason to the exclusion of our animal spirits. Lots of those folks are institutionalized, either in asylums, labs or universities.

There are two answers here, because there are (at least) two interpretations: Do humans engage in rational thought?Are humans engaging in rational thought all the time? Separating this out, you can see that the answer is yes, then no. In fact, rationality could be said to exist on a spectrum. The issue with this statement is the wrong implications that people can take: It is NOT correct that rational thoughts leads to more accurate assessments. It could be said, though, that they lead to more precise assessments, but that precision is not accuracy.It is NOT correct that those who engage in more rational thought are more consistent in their beliefs, despite that rationality could lead them toward consistency. In other words, there is a difference between consideration and actual belief revision. Meanwhile, intuitive thought has a tendency towards spreading out. It’s necessary to get someone out of a rational local minimum that they have created through limited perspectives and invalid assumptions that intuitive thought rely on breaking. In other words, rationality is useful, but so is intuitive thought.

No, humans are not fundamentally rational beings. I learned this during my first college psychology course. Humans are naturally emotional beings who tend to follow emotional impulses. In the Freudian model, the ID is the internal raging furnace of emotional energy that needs to become filtered through the Ego. Watch the development of any baby through the first six or seven years of age, and you can see the development of the Ego as it becomes more and more capable of channeling the emotional energy into practical actions. We are not born with natural ability for rational analytical thought. This takes education, training, and practice. Some people never get very good at it.

No. We are profoundly *irrational* creatures. The idea that the human mind is a thing of pure logic is untrue. Human intelligence and cognition did not evolve to make us logical, it evolved to allow us to navigate social relationships and to convince and influence others in our social group. Basically humans are a bunch of cold, naked, overexcitable primates with poorly acknowledged biological drives and urges, filtered through wayyyy too much processing power for our own good. If you want to understand, *really* understand how humans operate, do some reading up on primate groups in the wild. The patterns are exactly the same, just presented in much simpler form.
